s.text: This would create a `window of opportunity' in which a given thymocyte, in a given selecting location, could escape negative selection by antigens on the inactive X chromosome.
Thus, there may be time points at which certain thymic microenvironments are populated by dendritic cells that, for stochastic reasons, all utilize the same X chromosome.
In the normal females the AR gene is methylated on the inactive X chromosome and is undermethylated on the active X chromosome.
In addition, 30 healthy age-matched females were studied as normal controls.

One might examine X-inactivation skewing specifically in thymic dendritic populations, but if the effect is at the level of microenvironment and varies over time, then it will not be possible to detect this using methods directed at large cell populations, as we have done here.

This could be a chance event, or may result from selection for certain X-linked alleles during embryonic development, as has been described in carriers of X-linked immunodeficiencies [ 17].

Excessively long CAG repeats in the AR gene are a rare cause of spinal-bulbar muscular atrophy [ 13], and AR repeat length appears to have an influence on the biology of certain tumors [ 14, 15].
A major mechanism of peripheral tolerance induction appears to involve the recognition of tolerizing antigens by T cells in the absence of costimulation [ 19].
A unifying feature of autoimmune disorders appears to be the loss of immunologic tolerance to self-antigens, and in many of these diseases there is evidence that T-cell tolerance has been broken.
